string-array.name: QandA_A
string-array.item: No, it will always be free of charge. It will, however continue to develop over time to always give you the best experience possible!
Of course! Meat°it will continue to send you alerts/notifications even when working in the background.
Your meat°it probe alerts you: In the event of under-cooking (slow cooking), over-cooking (fast cooking), danger, when the food is ready as well as when you have programmed alerts. Bon appétit!
You can use meat°it with devices such as: Coal or gas BBQ, the Mastrad O’Plancha, frying pan, steam oven, smoker, rotisserie, plancha grill and oven. Any other use is not recommended.

No, because everyone has a different preference and we cannot decide that for you. You can however program a timer. You can also configure your own alerts. To do so, click the icon shaped like a “Bell” in Cooking control™; you can choose among the recommended alerts or personalize your own. For example: Remind me to turn the steak in 10’.
Yes, it also works with an induction stove.
No, absolutely not! Any use with a microwave is strictly proscribed by mastrad. You will cause irreversible damage to both your probe and your microwave.

Yes. You should however know that ovens and closed BBQs act as “semi” Faraday cages and will affect the signal range. In order to maintain the range, do not move your telephone/tablet any further than 16.5 feet/5 meters from the probe. Or use the wifi extension.

Make sure that Bluetooth is activated on your telephone. If your probe is not detected when inserted into your meat/fish, remove it using the probe extractor. Activate your probe using the docking station as indicated in the Quick Start Guide: “"Activate your meat°it probe by briefly placing the black part of the probe in the central section of the docking station. Take it out; it should be activated.” If this does not work, leave your probe to charge for at least 15 minutes. If the problem persists, contact Customer Service: meatit@mastrad.fr
If the probe is out of range, an audible and visual signal will warn you. Bring the probe closer so that the app can automatically reconnect.
No, absolutely not! You will totally destroy the probe and that would be a shame...
It can easily be cleaned under running water but do not immerse it; dry with a soft cloth. The docking station can be cleaned with a soft, dry cloth.

For total charge, you should plan on 2 hours. A 15-min charge will allow cooking time for up to 30 minutes. A green light will indicate when the probe is completely charged. Your probe will automatically switch off after 30 minutes of inactivity in order to preserve battery life.
Your probe offers more than 24 hours of use.
Your probe automatically switches off after 30 minutes of inactivity.
Your meat°it cooking probe is guaranteed for 2 years (1 year in the US) but we would be happy if you keep using it ;).
iOS version 9.1 or later.\nAndroid version 5.0 or later.\nBluetooth 4.0 or higher.

The best solution is to use the wifi extension. If that is impossible, you can try holding your telephone/tablet in a vertical position (or place it in a dock). This will give better results than laying it flat on a table or keeping it in your pocket. Also avoid laying your telephone/tablet on a metal surface. A well-charged probe transmits better than a little-charged one; avoid using meat°it when it is not fully charged ;). Finally, you should know that your probe transmits its Bluetooth signal from all of the black ceramic part and not only from the upper portion. You should thus ensure that the ceramic end piece is not totally covered and position your phone towards this piece in order to get the best results!

Because this is how the Android operating system is designed. It helps the system to detect and pair with your probe. But don’t worry, Mastrad does not use or even record your position under any circumstances.
In order to go from Celsius to Fahrenheit and vice-versa, go to the “Unit” tab in “Settings” and choose the one you prefer.

The quality of the meat°it engineering means that it can resist internal temperatures up to 212°F/100°C. As for ambient temperature, meat°it resists up to 572°F/300°C, which corresponds to the usual highest ambient cooking temperature. Moreover, the meat°it probe resists up to 3 minutes when in contact with open flame, in other words, a temperature of approximately 1270°F/700°C. An audible and visual alert will indicate when the probe is at risk.

Some recipes are available at: www.mastrad-paris.fr/recipes or on the dedicated site: www.meat-it.co. We will add to these recipes over time. You can send us your own recipes and receive special deals! meatit@mastrad.fr

Mea culpa! We tried to think of everything... You can “skip” this step at the bottom of the list; our algorithm will calculate the optimal cooking time depending on the type of meat you have selected. Send us an email and we’ll take care of the problem!
Yes, you can set your own personal temperature. At each step, a “personalized” button is available to let you configure your cooking as you like.

The quality of the meat°it engineering means that it can resist internal temperatures up to 212°F/100°C. Your meat, however, will probably be inedible if the core temperature goes beyond 195°F/90°C....

An efficient Faraday cage cannot have any hole if it is to be impervious to electromagnetic radio waves. Fortunately, ovens and barbecues are not built to be Faraday cages; they have many holes, plastic joints, ventilation systems, etc.\nNonetheless, concrete walls or metal linings can affect the Bluetooth signal. The quality of your signal is beyond our control; it depends on the structure of your home. "
People may mention organoleptic quality when talking about stimuli belonging to the senses such as flavor, taste, smell.
No, meat°it is not manufactured to be put in contact with liquids.
Yes, meat°it resists humidity; your probe will function as long as it is not immersed in a liquid.
We don’t recommend using meat°it for sous-vide cooking as the probe is not made to be immersed in liquid.
No, the pressure and humidity are much too high.

Since you ask: one of the meat°it secrets lies in the fact that it is the coolness of the meat that cools down the probe and its components and that allows it to resist such high temperatures. Imagine direct contact with a BBQ at 480°F/250°C....

The remaining time depends on the target temperature and on the meat temperature. For example, if the target temperature is 140°F/60°C, the remaining time will only show around 90°F/32°C. Before that temperature, the meat has not cooked long enough to calculate the cooking rate and thus the time remaining.
No, your probe will stop charging once the battery reaches 100%.
After several uses, the various metal parts may become covered in meat or grease. Make sure to clean them before charging your probe.
Because it serves no real purpose and because ovens and BBQs already show this information. We have gone one better: Cooking control™ calculates the cooking rate!
Slide towards the left to delete a line in the history.
That is the Cooking control™ shortcut! Click it and it will automatically take you to the last Cooking control™ that you viewed.
None! You can even copy/paste your favorite recipes from the Net. And we have planned something even better between now and summer of 2019...
Don’t worry! If you are connected to wifi, the second telephone is in “read-only” mode, you can only read the cooking information. Want to change something? Use your first telephone!

Setting up the probe is important for correct meat temperature readings.\n- Make sure you insert the metallic part completely and do not cover the black part of the probe, either with the meat or with parchment paper\n- Do not put the cooking dish with the probe too close to the sides of your device (at least 2 inches/5 cm).
Never! Some problems may take more time than others but, in any case, we promise to get back to you.

resources.string: HOW TO INSERT YOUR PROBE: FISH?
Fully insert the metal part of your probe into the thickest and densest part of the fish.
Be careful to prevent any air from entering so that the probe is fully covered by the flesh.
